title: Federal Court reinstates bans in Prime Trust case
text:
A full bench of the Federal Court has moved to reinstate bans and fines against the former federal health minister Dr Michael Wooldridge and other board members of the a collapsed retirement village trust after the corporate watchdog won a landmark directors duties' case.

The Federal Court judgement follows a seven-year legal battle which the Australian Securities and Investments Commission fought all the way to the High Court.

Former federal health minister Michael Wooldridge. Luis Ascui

ASIC won its appeal in the High Court late last year. The High Court ruled declarations the directors, including Dr Wooldridge and the trust's founder Bill Lewski, had breached their duties be reinstated and directed the Federal Court to redetermine penalties and disqualification periods.

In its decision last week the Federal Court effectively re-imposed director fines and bans that had been partly served, although a further hearing is due later this month to hear applications on those bans, including from Dr Wooldridge.

The case hinges not on the 2010 collapse itself of Prime Retirement and Aged Care Property Trust, but on the directors' approval for the controversial payment of a $33 million listing fee to Prime's founder, Bill Lewski, after the trust went public.
